thread.title: College football | Otterbein continues recent mastery of Capital | Buckeye Xtra Sports
thread.title_full: College football | Otterbein continues recent mastery of Capital | Buckeye Xtra Sports

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: College football | Otterbein continues recent mastery of Capital | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
The rivalry between Otterbein and Capital seemingly had reached the "anything you can do I can do better" stage when Crusaders quarterback Zak Sheridan ran 8 yards to set up fourth-and-goal at the 1-yard line in the second quarter.
Only 36 more inches and the score would be tied at two touchdowns apiece in an interesting tug 'o war.
But the Cardinals pulled off two spectacular plays in less than 20 seconds to get started toward a 49-34 victory before a standing-room crowd of more than 3,000 on Saturday in Bernlohr Stadium.
It is the first time since 1996-99 that Otterbein (3-2) has won four straight in the series between universities that are 14 miles apart.
“When we come into this game, it is a one-game season," Cardinals senior safety Jordan Bonifas of Dublin Coffman said.
Bonifas played as though that fourth down was a season in itself as he and others swarmed Sheridan for no gain on a sneak attempt.
Sheridan rushed the offense to the line in an attempt to snap the ball quickly and catch Otterbein in disarray.
“They were driving down the field that whole series, and we said, ‘It’s right here and right now,'" Bonifas said. “We got the quarterback in the dirt. We figured it was something they would try to do on that play, and we were ready."
The next task was for the offense to get breathing room, and coach Tim Doup’s first impulse was to call a play-action pass.
That thought quickly disappeared for quarterback Kevan Green when Capital blitzed in order to plug the gaps to keep the Cardinals pinned.
Senior John Pyles of Franklin Heights burst through the left side of the line and ran 99 yards for a touchdown to make it 21-7 with 10:20 left in the first half.
“My thinking there was to protect the ball and get away from the goal line," Pyles said. “I didn’t think I got touched. I just wanted to run as fast as I could and don’t get caught."
Had he been tackled from behind, Pyles would have never lived it down with his teammates on the track team. He ran a leg on the 4x100 relay team that finished eighth in the NCAA Division III meet last spring.
“I was thinking, ‘You have to finish strong,'" said Pyles, who finished with 193 yards on the ground. “I think our offensive line stepped up the entire game. We had a balance of running and passing, and that had a great effect."
Green got the best view of the play and liked what he saw once Pyles ran into the line.
“There was a small hole and when he got through there was nobody there -- nobody," he said. “He’s fast, a great athlete. He was gone. I like to run up the field to follow the play, but I was walking at midfield."
The game changed for good when Otterbein recovered a fumble on the ensuing kickoff at the Capital 33.
Five plays later, sophomore receiver Julian Lowe of Gahanna ran 18 yards for a touchdown on a jet sweep to make it 28-7.
“Our guys calmed down -- relaxed -- after the (Pyles touchdown)," Doup said. “When we got the fumble on the kickoff, we said they could be in a little bit of trouble if we score here."
Capital (2-3) got within 28-14 on a 1-yard run by Nick Waters of Hilliard Davidson with 1:56 left in the second quarter.
The Cardinals responded by going 75 yards in four plays for a touchdown, a 37-yard pass from Green to Logan Stepp of West Jefferson with 50 seconds left in the half to make it 35-14.
Green said it was about time the play, a skinny post in the back of the end zone, worked.
“That play, we probably run it every game," Green said. “I either overthrow it or the protection breaks down. Finally, we connected. That was a big play."
mznidar@dispatch.com 
@markznidar
